Frank and André have worked together before on “Pink Matter.” This is also the only track on Blonde where Frank is not singing, though Frank has stated in the past that the album is entirely autobiographical. Where in “Solo”, Frank is physically alone by not being in a relationship Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: An interlude reprising the themes from the earlier track of the same name, performed by André 3000 of OutKast and featuring vocals from English singer and songwriter James Blake. Frank and André have worked together before on “Pink Matter.” This is also the only track on Blonde where Frank is not singing, though Frank has stated in the past that the album is entirely autobiographical. Where in “Solo”, Frank is physically alone by not being in a relationship, in “Reprise” he reflects on the music industry and modern society, feeling alone in his beliefs. He uses the perspective of André, a well-established artist, as Frank and André both may have felt alone this way after achieving success in the music industry. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

lastfm_wiki_summary: Grande’s track “the boy is mine” functions as an indirect sequel to her leaked, unreleased song, commonly referred to by fans as “fantasize”, which went viral on platforms such as TikTok in 2023. Since then, many fans have clamored for a real 90s-inspired R&B/Pop record from her. Prior to the song’s release, in an interview on Apple Music with Zane Lowe, Ariana details how “the boy is mine” and “true story” work as sister tracks, where “the boy is mine” is the ‘bad girl anthem’ that “true story” sets up. Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: Grande’s track “the boy is mine” functions as an indirect sequel to her leaked, unreleased song, commonly referred to by fans as “fantasize”, which went viral on platforms such as TikTok in 2023. Since then, many fans have clamored for a real 90s-inspired R&B/Pop record from her. Prior to the song’s release, in an interview on Apple Music with Zane Lowe, Ariana details how “the boy is mine” and “true story” work as sister tracks, where “the boy is mine” is the ‘bad girl anthem’ that “true story” sets up. On the provocative nature of the song and amid accusations of being a homewrecker, she said: "This is a very bad idea, I think, but… There is a large group of my fans that really do love a bad girl anthem. And this is kind of an elevated version of that." Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

lastfm_wiki_summary: In "Never Be Me", Miley reflects on the expectations that her lovers hold against her, reminding them that she will never be the type of woman to fit into a specific mold. The track is one of the few which Miley had intended to release as part of her 2019 EP series. At the time, the track was titled "I Play with Fire" due to the line in the verse and was situated as the twelth and penultimate track on the album. Read more on Last.fm.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "Sunday Morning" is the fourth single from Maroon 5's debut album, Songs About Jane. Released in 2004, the single peaked at #31 in the USA becoming Maroon 5's fourth Top 40 single; it also peaked at #27 in the U.K and #7 in Latin America becoming Maroon 5's third consecutive Top 10 single. The video for the song was shot on October 17-18, 2004. It was shot at Abbey Road Studios in London, the same studio at which the Beatles recorded their famous Abbey Road album. Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: "Sunday Morning" is the fourth single from Maroon 5's debut album, Songs About Jane. Released in 2004, the single peaked at #31 in the USA becoming Maroon 5's fourth Top 40 single; it also peaked at #27 in the U.K and #7 in Latin America becoming Maroon 5's third consecutive Top 10 single. The video for the song was shot on October 17-18, 2004. It was shot at Abbey Road Studios in London, the same studio at which the Beatles recorded their famous Abbey Road album. The song has also been featured on the soundtracks of Something's Gotta Give and Love Actually and (although the latter was the 1.22.03.Acoustic version). Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

lastfm_wiki_summary: The song “We Major” is an anthem of success, celebration and camaraderie; it’s a reminder that greatness can be achieved, recognition deserves to be given, and no dream is too big. The song is composed of three verses and a chorus. Throughout the song, Kanye West, Nas, and Really Doe are reflecting on their rise to the top, hustling their way to success and the realities of life in the projects. They talk about reaching their goals despite growing up with nothing and facing adversity. Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: The song “We Major” is an anthem of success, celebration and camaraderie; it’s a reminder that greatness can be achieved, recognition deserves to be given, and no dream is too big. The song is composed of three verses and a chorus. Throughout the song, Kanye West, Nas, and Really Doe are reflecting on their rise to the top, hustling their way to success and the realities of life in the projects. They talk about reaching their goals despite growing up with nothing and facing adversity. The chorus is inspired by the idea of rising from the ground up; from the hood to the skyscraper and from nothing to something, everything is achievable through dedication and hard work. Throughout the song, the artists are encouraging people to stay strong, celebrate their successes and never give up on what they truly want. The song is ultimately a reminder that although life may be filled with struggles, with determination, anything is possible. A cut off of Kanye’s Late Registration best known for Nas' verse. This helped close the gap between Jay-Z and Nas' feud, since Kanye and Jay are closely associated. Jay even called this song his favorite off of the album. Read more on Last.fm. lastfm_wiki_summary: Released as the fourth single from his 2004 debut album The College Dropout, Jesus Walks was produced by West. The song is built upon a sample of gospel hymn "Walk With Me" by The ARC Choir, a group of reformed drug addicts based New York. Written by West, rapper and friend Che Smith (who performs as Rhymefest), and violinist Miri Ben-Ari, the song was universally acclaimed by music critics, who praised its compelling sonic atmosphere and boldness in its open embrace of faith. Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: Released as the fourth single from his 2004 debut album The College Dropout, Jesus Walks was produced by West. The song is built upon a sample of gospel hymn "Walk With Me" by The ARC Choir, a group of reformed drug addicts based New York. Written by West, rapper and friend Che Smith (who performs as Rhymefest), and violinist Miri Ben-Ari, the song was universally acclaimed by music critics, who praised its compelling sonic atmosphere and boldness in its open embrace of faith. Various publications placed the song on several year and decade-end lists, and have since listed it among the greatest of all time. Read more on Last.fm. lastfm_wiki_summary: “Seek & Destroy“ is the third track on SZA's sophomore album SOS. This song explores the destructive capacities of love. Rather than heal, it hurts. Although the pain motivates SZA to take drastic actions that presumably “ruin everything”, she feels freer than ever without her demanding man. Read more on Last.fm.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "Misery" is a song performed by The Beatles on their album Please Please Me. It was co-written by John Lennon and Paul McCartney. According to Lennon, "It was kind of a John song more than a Paul song, but it was written together." McCartney was to say: "I don't think either one of us dominated on that one, it was just a hacking job." Read more on Last.fm.

lastfm_wiki_summary: On “Solo,” Frank touches on various aspects of being alone, such as self-love or waiting for a call from your lover. It’s not entirely clear if this song is specifically about experiences he’s had. The song’s title has two interpretations. Throughout the song, Frank sings about how he is alone, or solo, but, through the chorus Frank explains that he’s “so low” emotionally and that he needs to “get high.” Read more on Last.fm.

lastfm_wiki_content: "All Too Well" was the first song written for Red. While collaborating with different writers on Red, Swift wrote the song along with Liz Rose. The song was inspired by Swift's ex-boyfriend Jake Gyllenhaal, according to some speculation. Swift has said that the song was "the hardest to write on the album", saying "'it [was difficult to write emotionally] because it took me a really long time to filter through everything I wanted to put in the song without it being a 10 minute song, which you can’t put on an album. I wanted a story that could work in the form of a song and I called my co-writer Liz Rose and said, ‘Come over, we’ve gotta filter this down,’ and it took me a really long time to get it." lastfm_wiki_summary: BODYGUARD” is the eighth song on Beyoncé’s studio album, COWBOY CARTER. The production on this song is a bit of a departure from the previous songs of the album in terms of a “classic country” sound, becoming a bit more chill. This is what she meant in her Instragram post when she said: “This ain’t a Country album. This is a “Beyoncé” album”. The lyrics of the song shows a seductive Beyoncé, offering to her lover the same protection as a bodyguard could bring to him. Read more on Last.fm.

lastfm_wiki_summary: “Lucky Strike“ is a song by American band Maroon 5 recorded for their fourth studio album, Overexposed. It was written by Adam Levine together with Ryan Tedder and Noel Zancanella who also served as producers of the song. "Lucky Strike" is a funk song that features dubstep and soul rock influences. Lyrically, it discovers the theme of sexual intercourse. The song received generally positive reviews from music critics who found it catchy and labeled it as one of the best tracks on Overexposed. Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: “Lucky Strike“ is a song by American band Maroon 5 recorded for their fourth studio album, Overexposed. It was written by Adam Levine together with Ryan Tedder and Noel Zancanella who also served as producers of the song. "Lucky Strike" is a funk song that features dubstep and soul rock influences. Lyrically, it discovers the theme of sexual intercourse. The song received generally positive reviews from music critics who found it catchy and labeled it as one of the best tracks on Overexposed. Following the release of the album, due to strong digital downloads, the song peaked at number two on the singles chart in South Korea and at number nine on the US Bubbling Under Hot 100 Singles. The song was included on the set list for Maroon 5's fourth worldwide tour, the Overexposed Tour (2012–13). It was also included in the set list of their 2015 self-titled world tour in support of their fifth studio album, V. “Lucky Strike“ was written by Maroon 5's lead singer Adam Levine together with Ryan Tedder and Noel Zancanella, who also served as producers of the song. Tedder and Zancanella also co-wrote and co-produced another song for Overexposed titled "Love Somebody". "Lucky Strike" was engineered by Smith Carlson at the Patriot Studios in Denver and Noah "Mailbox" Passovoy at the Conway Studios in Los Angeles; Eric Eylands served as the engineering assistant. Serban Ghenea mixed the song at the Mixstar Studios in Virginia Beach. John Hanes served as engineer for mix, while Phil Seaford as mixing assistant. All the programming and keys were provided by Tedder and Zancanella. “Lucky Strike“ is a funk song that features dubstep and soul influences and lasts for three minutes and five seconds. The song's instrumentation consists of piano, "driven guitar" accompanied with Levine's vocals. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "The Last Time" is a song by Taylor Swift featuring Gary Lightbody, taken from Swift's fourth studio album, Red (2012). Swift wrote the track with Lightbody and Jacknife Lee; the latter two are members of the rock band Snow Patrol. A power ballad, the song sees Swift's and Lightbody's characters expressing their perspectives on a failed relationship, torn between heartbreak and forgiveness. The production combines alternative rock and folk over dramatic string instruments and an orchestral background in the refrain. Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: "The Last Time" is a song by Taylor Swift featuring Gary Lightbody, taken from Swift's fourth studio album, Red (2012). Swift wrote the track with Lightbody and Jacknife Lee; the latter two are members of the rock band Snow Patrol. A power ballad, the song sees Swift's and Lightbody's characters expressing their perspectives on a failed relationship, torn between heartbreak and forgiveness. The production combines alternative rock and folk over dramatic string instruments and an orchestral background in the refrain. "The Last Time" was released in the United Kingdom on November 4, 2013, as a single from Red. Critics praised "The Last Time" for its production and Lightbody's performance, but some felt that Lightbody's and Swift's vocals do not complement each other. Retrospectively, they considered it one of Swift's weakest songs in her discography. Commercially, the song reached the top 30 on singles charts in Ireland, Scotland, and the UK. A re-recorded version, "The Last Time (Taylor's Version)", was included on Swift's re-recorded album Red (Taylor's Version), released on November 12, 2021. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

It is the seventeenth and final song on the deluxe album, and was released to streaming and digital platforms on August 18, 2020. Written and produced by Swift and Jack Antonoff, "The Lakes" is a midtempo indie ballad, set to acoustic guitar and strings Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: "The Lakes" (stylized in all lowercase) is a song recorded by American singer-songwriter Taylor Swift, taken from the deluxe edition of her eighth studio album, Folklore (2020), released on August 7, 2020 through Republic Records. It is the seventeenth and final song on the deluxe album, and was released to streaming and digital platforms on August 18, 2020. Written and produced by Swift and Jack Antonoff, "The Lakes" is a midtempo indie ballad, set to acoustic guitar and strings, with themes of introspection and escapism that reflect on Swift's semi-retirement in Windermere, the largest lake in England. Upon release, "The Lakes" received universal acclaim from music critics, with compliments on its sophisticated, poetic lyrics, and melancholic instrumentals; many named it a highlight on Folklore and one of the best songs Swift has ever penned. The song debuted in the top-10 of the Canadian and US Digital Song Sales charts, and reached number 13 in New Zealand, number 21 in Scotland and UK Downloads, and number 28 in Hungary. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

Premiered at the 67th Annual Grammy Awards, the song has been praised for its dark, theatrical style and energetic production. Critics highlighted its intense Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: "Abracadabra" is the third single from Lady Gaga's seventh studio album, MAYHEM. The track blends electronic and house influences with pulsating beats, hypnotic synths, and dramatic vocals, reminiscent of her The Fame Monster and Chromatica eras. It also incorporates a melody from Siouxsie and the Banshees' "Spellbound". Premiered at the 67th Annual Grammy Awards, the song has been praised for its dark, theatrical style and energetic production. Critics highlighted its intense, catchy chorus, Europop-inspired climax, and Gaga's powerful vocal performance. It achieved 4.92 million Spotify streams on its first day, marking her biggest solo debut on the platform. The music video, co-directed by Gaga, Parris Goebel, and Bethany Vargas, features a dramatic dance battle between two versions of Gaga—one in red latex, representing control, and the other in white, symbolizing chaos. The choreography reflects themes of duality, resilience, and the struggle between light and darkness. Critics compared its aesthetics to "Bad Romance" and praised its high-fashion visuals and dynamic energy. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "Carmen" is a cautionary tale on the dangers of addiction and the risks involved in leading a life of excess. The song tells the story of a young woman named Carmen, who despite her captivating allure, is struggling with addiction, loneliness, and eventually meets her demise. The lyrics describe her as charming, disarming, and a confidant of sorts, but also as a liar who is deceiving everyone around her about her struggles. In the first verse, Carmen is depicted as someone who has access to top-shelf liquor Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: "Carmen" is a cautionary tale on the dangers of addiction and the risks involved in leading a life of excess. The song tells the story of a young woman named Carmen, who despite her captivating allure, is struggling with addiction, loneliness, and eventually meets her demise. The lyrics describe her as charming, disarming, and a confidant of sorts, but also as a liar who is deceiving everyone around her about her struggles. In the first verse, Carmen is depicted as someone who has access to top-shelf liquor, which may be an indication of her dangerous indulgences. The pre-chorus and chorus describe her as being popular amongst boys and girls alike, with her charismatic and seductive persona, but she warns them not to be like her. She acknowledges her own addiction and the toll it's taking on her life. The second verse portrays Carmen as a young girl who is already walking the streets at night, portraying a dangerous and risky lifestyle. The lyrics hint at the fact that Carmen is using drugs to cope with her struggles, leaving her disarming and alarming to those around her who care for her well-being. The bridge suggests that Carmen is relying on the kindness of strangers and is engaging in risky behavior such as using drugs and participating in party favors. The interlude adds a layer of tragic love to the story, with Carmen's lover confessing to being unable to live without her, and Carmen willing to do anything for him. The song's haunting outro returns to the lyrical theme of Carmen's addiction - that she has a problem but continues to drink from her top-shelf liquor. Read more on Last.fm. lastfm_wiki_summary: "The Tourist" was written by Jonny, who, explains Thom, was "in a beautiful square in France on a sunny day, and watching all these American tourists being wheeled around, frantically trying to see everything in 10 minutes." Jonny was shocked at how these people could be in a place so beautiful and so special and not realize it because they weren't taking the time to just stop and look around. Jonny : "Thom didn't play a thing, he just listened. It's quite nervy, with a lot of space. It sounds like the last song on an album." Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: "The Tourist" was written by Jonny, who, explains Thom, was "in a beautiful square in France on a sunny day, and watching all these American tourists being wheeled around, frantically trying to see everything in 10 minutes." Jonny was shocked at how these people could be in a place so beautiful and so special and not realize it because they weren't taking the time to just stop and look around. Jonny : "Thom didn't play a thing, he just listened. It's quite nervy, with a lot of space. It sounds like the last song on an album." Metaphor : People live very fast and overloading, better live in the moment, live slowly, looking at the present and not the goals that make you unhappy. It is like a tourist trying to photograph everything and not enjoying the scenery. :] Read more on Last.fm. lastfm_wiki_content: “Flowers” is the two-time, Grammy-winning lead single from Miley Cyrus' eighth studio album Endless Summer Vacation. The song is about her past relationship with ex-husband Liam Hemsworth, releasing the track on his birthday, with lyrics implying she doesn’t need him to fulfill her happiness. Cyrus first teased the new era with cryptic posters around the world that featured lyrics and a release date. Fans were skeptical about it, until she later dropped the first teaser on New Year’s Eve, along with announcing the single’s title and release date. Minutes later, a second teaser was released. A music video for the single was accompanied with the single’s release. The song heavily interpolates and draws upon the themes of Bruno Mars' 2012 song When I Was Your Man, and can be seen in some regards as a spiritual successor and a "response" to Mars' song from the perspective of the other party in a failed relationship. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "Lost in Japan" is a song recorded by Canadian singer Shawn Mendes. It was written by Mendes, Scott Harris, Nate Mercereau and Teddy Geiger, with production handled by Mendes, Mercereau, Geiger and Louis Bell. The song was released by Island Records on March 23, 2018, as a second single for Mendes' self-titled third studio album. An official remix by German music producer Zedd was released on September 27, 2018. "Lost in Japan" is a funk, pop and R&B song Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: "Lost in Japan" is a song recorded by Canadian singer Shawn Mendes. It was written by Mendes, Scott Harris, Nate Mercereau and Teddy Geiger, with production handled by Mendes, Mercereau, Geiger and Louis Bell. The song was released by Island Records on March 23, 2018, as a second single for Mendes' self-titled third studio album. An official remix by German music producer Zedd was released on September 27, 2018. "Lost in Japan" is a funk, pop and R&B song, with "funky strings and driving bass" that bears resemblances to the work of Justin Timberlake. During interviews, Mendes stated that he was inspired by all of the Timberlake songs he was listening to at the time, especially Justified–and a dream. "I had this dream that I was lost in this country and I woke up the next day and we had this cool piano part and the song was birthed." Lars Brandle of Billboard wrote that the song "opens with a subtle spell of piano then changes gears with a fat bass sound and groove". It transformed from "a slow, piano-driven number" into "a passionate, hook-laden love song", according to CBS Radio's Robyn Collins. Lyrically, Mendes offers to travel the globe in order to be closer to his love interest. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

lastfm_wiki_summary: Beyoncé surprised everyone by dropping new song "Formation" a day before the Super Bowl 50, complete with a provocative and empowering video. "Formation" was made available for free for a limited time on TIDAL and was performed by Beyoncé for the first time during the Super Bowl 50 halftime show. The release was followed by a controversy when Beyoncé and video director Melina Matsoukas were accused of taking scenes directly from That B.E.A.T., a mini-documentary about the New Orleans bounce movement. Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: Beyoncé surprised everyone by dropping new song "Formation" a day before the Super Bowl 50, complete with a provocative and empowering video. "Formation" was made available for free for a limited time on TIDAL and was performed by Beyoncé for the first time during the Super Bowl 50 halftime show. The release was followed by a controversy when Beyoncé and video director Melina Matsoukas were accused of taking scenes directly from That B.E.A.T., a mini-documentary about the New Orleans bounce movement. The video also features several appearances from Beyoncé's daughter, Blue Ivy and husband Jay Z. The song has been described as one of Beyoncé's most political works, calling African American women to stand side by side, in formation. Read more on Last.fm. lastfm_wiki_summary: "Doin' Time" is a song by American ska-punk band Sublime, covered by Lana Del Rey. It is a commentary on the contradiction between pleasure-seeking and its consequences. The song paints a picture of two people, the narrator and her friend, who are drawn to the thrill of being young and living life to its fullest. At the same time, they know that this lifestyle comes with certain risks – they're locked in a relationship where the narrator is mistreated and they're doing "harder" things that may come with unpleasant outcomes. Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: "Doin' Time" is a song by American ska-punk band Sublime, covered by Lana Del Rey. It is a commentary on the contradiction between pleasure-seeking and its consequences. The song paints a picture of two people, the narrator and her friend, who are drawn to the thrill of being young and living life to its fullest. At the same time, they know that this lifestyle comes with certain risks – they're locked in a relationship where the narrator is mistreated and they're doing "harder" things that may come with unpleasant outcomes. The chorus of the song lyrically captures this tension with the juxtaposition between the summertime ease that the two feel and the fact that the activities they're participating in are dangerous. Ultimately, the narrator comes to the realization that she is in control of her own fate in this regard – she's able to remove the "veil from off her eyes" to see the bigger picture and can choose to stay away from people and activities that will drag her down. It is the fifth track of Lana Del Rey's sixth studio album, Norman Fucking Rockwell! Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "Greedy" is the seventh track on Ariana Grande's third studio album Dangerous Woman. On the track, she speaks about an insatiable desire for love and affection from someone. She is obsessed with this person and is not afraid to admit it. She expresses how she has never felt these feelings and wants to make it obvious. Additionally, she emphasizes the importance of owning her emotions instead of denying them. Read more on Last.fm.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "Strip It Down" is a song co-written and recorded by American country music artist Luke Bryan. It was first released to digital retailers as the first promotional single from his fifth studio album, Kill the Lights (2015), on July 17, 2015 and was released to radio on August 4, 2015 as the album's second official single. The song was written by Bryan, Jon Nite and Ross Copperman, and produced by Jeff and Jody Stevens. Read more on Last.fm.

lastfm_wiki_summary: “COFFEE BEAN” revolves around Travis' initially tumultuous relationship with his girlfriend and baby mother Kylie Jenner. He discusses the backlash and controversy that has come as a result of their relationship. The song is one of Travis' most personal yet, detailing many of his inner fears and insecurities; it is arguably his most revealing and vulnerable song to date. Additionally, the soothing boom-bap production is unusual for Travis, who is well-known for his genre-bending contributions to trap music. Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: “COFFEE BEAN” revolves around Travis' initially tumultuous relationship with his girlfriend and baby mother Kylie Jenner. He discusses the backlash and controversy that has come as a result of their relationship. The song is one of Travis' most personal yet, detailing many of his inner fears and insecurities; it is arguably his most revealing and vulnerable song to date. Additionally, the soothing boom-bap production is unusual for Travis, who is well-known for his genre-bending contributions to trap music. It should also be noted that there is a popular coffee chain in Los Angeles (Travis and Kylie’s home) called The Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf, which is typically shortened to “Coffee Bean.” Throughout the song, Travis alternates between being on and off the coffee bean, which represents the internal struggle that Travis feels in regards to his relationship with now ex-girlfriend Kylie Jenner. The term “bean” is also commonly used to refer to Ecstacy, although it is unclear if that is what Travis is referring to. “COFFEE BEAN,” debuted at #68 on the Billboard Hot 100 during the week of August 18th, 2018. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "Love Me Do" is The Beatles' first single, backed by "P.S. I Love You" and released on 5 October 1962. When the single was originally released in the United Kingdom, it peaked at number seventeen; in 1982 it was re-issued and reached number four. In the United States the single was a number one hit in 1964. In January 2013, the Beatles' recording of "Love Me Do" entered the public domain in Europe/Canada, as sound recordings were copyright-protected for 50 years. The copyright term was later extended to 70 years, which was not retroactive. Read more on Last.fm.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "Vanish into You" is a 2025 song by Lady Gaga. It was originally released as the fifth track on her studio album Mayhem (2025) and was the first song she wrote for the album.[3] Andrew Watt, Henry Walter, and Michael Polansky are co-writers. "Vanish into You" was written by Lady Gaga, Andrew Watt, Henry Walter, and Michael Polansky. Paper magazine has called the song "a discovery of love".[4] Riff magazine said the song sees Gaga "[channel] Blondie with a four-on-the-floor rhythm that's rooted in funk. Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: "Vanish into You" is a 2025 song by Lady Gaga. It was originally released as the fifth track on her studio album Mayhem (2025) and was the first song she wrote for the album.[3] Andrew Watt, Henry Walter, and Michael Polansky are co-writers. "Vanish into You" was written by Lady Gaga, Andrew Watt, Henry Walter, and Michael Polansky. Paper magazine has called the song "a discovery of love".[4] Riff magazine said the song sees Gaga "[channel] Blondie with a four-on-the-floor rhythm that's rooted in funk. The track explores merging identity with a partner's to insulate from emotions".[5] Variety called the track a "David Bowie-referencing"[6] song that "builds towards its chorus with the same tension" as "Bad Romance" (2009).[7] Pitchfork has said "Vanish into You" has "pining yelps".[8] Clash magazine said the song "drops the tempo a little" and has "disco-fringed synths recalling ABBA's imperial phase; there's a slight retro touch at times here, too".[9] Some fans theorized that the song was inspired by Gaga's late collaborator Tony Bennett, highlighting lyrics which were reminiscent of some of Bennett's most popular songs.[10] Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "The Next Best American Record" is a song that celebrates a past relationship that was inspired by creativity and a shared love for music. It suggests a carefree and fun-loving dynamic, while also emphasizing the importance of personal connections and relationships. The song reflects on a past romance where the two individuals involved were so consumed by their desire to create "the next best American record" that it became all they thought and talked about. Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: "The Next Best American Record" is a song that celebrates a past relationship that was inspired by creativity and a shared love for music. It suggests a carefree and fun-loving dynamic, while also emphasizing the importance of personal connections and relationships. The song reflects on a past romance where the two individuals involved were so consumed by their desire to create "the next best American record" that it became all they thought and talked about. The lyrics suggest a carefree and exciting relationship where the two were just happy to be with each other, lost in their creativity and love. The lines "My baby used to dance underneath my architecture" and "He was '70s in spirit, '90s in his frame of mind" suggest a certain nostalgia for the past and the idea that the two were inspired by the music and culture of earlier decades. There is also a sense of longing and reminiscence in the repeated line "My baby used to dance underneath my architecture". The chorus discusses the desire to let loose and have fun, with the speaker expressing their desire to simply party and enjoy themselves, particularly in the line "Topanga's hot tonight, I'm taking off my bathing suit". However, this desire to let loose is tied to the presence of the other person: "You make me feel like there's something that I never knew I wanted". The bridge of the song further emphasizes the importance of the other person, with the repeated lines "all the roads lead to you" and "I see you for who you really are". The mention of Bill playing guitar suggests a specific individual, perhaps someone she admires or is inspired by. It is the tenth track from Lana Del Rey's sixth studio album, Norman Fucking Rockwell! Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "How to Disappear Completely" is a song by the English rock band Radiohead from their fourth studio album "Kid A". It was produced by the band with their producer, Nigel Godrich. The song is titled after Doug Richmond's 1985 book "How to Disappear Completely and Never Be Found". The band first performed the song in 1998 during the tour. An early soundcheck performance features in the 1998 documentary "Meeting People Is Easy". During the "Kid A" sessions in 1999 Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: "How to Disappear Completely" is a song by the English rock band Radiohead from their fourth studio album "Kid A". It was produced by the band with their producer, Nigel Godrich. The song is titled after Doug Richmond's 1985 book "How to Disappear Completely and Never Be Found". The band first performed the song in 1998 during the tour. An early soundcheck performance features in the 1998 documentary "Meeting People Is Easy". During the "Kid A" sessions in 1999, Radiohead recorded demos for the song in various studios, until it was recorded at their Oxfordshire studio at the end of January, 2000. In early February, the strings were recorded and performed by the Orchestra of St John's inside a church near the band's studio, composed by the multi-instrumentalist Jonny Greenwood on an ondes Martenot. An isolated strings track was included on the compilation "Kid Amnesia". “That song is about the whole period of time that "OK Computer" was happening. We did the Glastonbury Festival and this thing in Ireland. Something snapped in me. I just said, ‘That’s it. I can’t take it anymore.’ And more than a year later, we were still on the road. I hadn’t had time to address things. The lyrics came from something Michael Stipe said to me. I rang him and said, ‘I cannot cope with this.’ And he said, ‘Pull the shutters down and keep saying, 'I’m not here, this is not happening.’” — Thom Yorke Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "Watermelon Sugar" is a song by English singer Harry Styles from his second studio album "Fine Line", included as the album's second track. Styles wrote the song with Mitch Rowland and its producers Tyler Johnson and Kid Harpoon. They were inspired by the 1968 American novel "In Watermelon Sugar" by Richard Brautigan. "Watermelon Sugar" is a horn and guitar-driven rock, funk-pop, and indie pop song. Read more on Last.fm.

lastfm_wiki_content: "I'll Be Back" is a song written by John Lennon, with some collaboration from Paul McCartney (credited to Lennon/McCartney). It was recorded by the English rock band the Beatles for the soundtrack album to their film A Hard Day's Night (1964) but not used in the film. This song was not released in North America until Beatles '65 five months later. The Beatles recorded "I'll Be Back" in 16 takes on 1 June 1964. The first nine were of the rhythm track, and the last seven were overdubs of the lead and harmony vocals, and an acoustic guitar overdub. Read more on Last.fm. lastfm_wiki_content: The futuristic-esque title track and first promotional single released off of Dua Lipa's sophomore album, Future Nostalgia, as it's opening track. was first teased by the British singer-songwriter on her interview with Heart Breakfast back in November of 2019: - "When I announce my album title, which will be early December, I’m gonna put out the album title track and like a little a video." In the empowering feminist anthem, Lipa can be heard singing about how confident she feels while proudly referring to herself as a strong and optimistic "female alpha." Hours before its official US release, Dua took to social media to announce the song. Compared to other tracks, “Future Nostalgia” has a more experimental sound. The artist herself described it as “playful and fun and not […] too serious.” Was written by Lipa, Jeff Bhasker & Clarence Coffee Jr., and co-produced by Bhasker & Skylar Mones. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "Parachute" is a song recorded by singer-songwriter Chris Stapleton. It is the third single from his debut album Traveller. The song was written by Stapleton and Jim Beavers. The song is an uptempo backed by banjo and acoustic guitar, in which the narrator sings about being there for the one he loves: "Baby, I will be your parachute". Stapleton sang "Parachute" live at the CMT Music Awards in June 2016, with assistance from Dave Cobb, Mickey Raphael, Robby Turner, and Stapleton's wife, Morgane. Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: "Parachute" is a song recorded by singer-songwriter Chris Stapleton. It is the third single from his debut album Traveller. The song was written by Stapleton and Jim Beavers. The song is an uptempo backed by banjo and acoustic guitar, in which the narrator sings about being there for the one he loves: "Baby, I will be your parachute". Stapleton sang "Parachute" live at the CMT Music Awards in June 2016, with assistance from Dave Cobb, Mickey Raphael, Robby Turner, and Stapleton's wife, Morgane. He also performed the song on the January 16, 2016 edition of Saturday Night Live. Read more on Last.fm. Scott is also using a double-entendre with “butterfly” wherein Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: “BUTTERFLY EFFECT” is Travis Scott’s first solo release of 2017, serving as the lead single to his third studio album, ASTROWORLD, which released more than a year after this song. It is produced by Murda Beatz, who has worked with Travis previously, most notably on September 2016’s “sweet sweet” and “outside.” The “butterfly effect” is a concept that explains and proves how small causes can have large effects. Scott is also using a double-entendre with “butterfly” wherein, as he refers to the doors on his Lamborghini car; he also describes moving to his new life, how great it is, and how he could never go back to the old one. On May 15, 2017, Travis released the track on SoundCloud, along with two other songs: “A Man” and “Green & Purple (feat. Playboi Carti).” However, “BUTTERFLY EFFECT” was the only one out of the three songs that was released as a proper single onto streaming services. The official music video was released almost two months after, on July 13, 2017. Travis Scott first performed this song live on Wednesday night, 17th May for his Birds Eye View Tour in St. Louis. Travis also performed the song at the VMAs with 30 Seconds to Mars and solo (atop a flying bird) at the EMAs. “BUTTERFLY EFFECT” was certified RIAA Double Platinum on January 25th, 2018, debuting at number 99 on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart and peaking at number 50 during the week of August 18th, 2018. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

It was written by Grande, Victoria Monét, Tayla Parx, Savan Kotecha and its producers Max Martin and Ilya Salmanzadeh. The song reflects on the emotional toll of being in a new relationship while mourning the loss of her ex-boyfriend and late rapper, Mac Miller. The lyrics suggest a sense of heartache, internal conflict, and lingering emotions. During the Thank U Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: "ghostin" is a song by Ariana Grande from her fifth studio album, thank u, next (2019). It was written by Grande, Victoria Monét, Tayla Parx, Savan Kotecha and its producers Max Martin and Ilya Salmanzadeh. The song reflects on the emotional toll of being in a new relationship while mourning the loss of her ex-boyfriend and late rapper, Mac Miller. The lyrics suggest a sense of heartache, internal conflict, and lingering emotions. During the Thank U, Next interview at the Zach Sang Show, Ariana revealed that Scooter forced her to include ghostin on the album when she begged him not to include the song. Commercially, the song reached #25 on the Billboard Hot 100, after the release of her album. Read more on Last.fm. lastfm_wiki_content: “supernatural“ yields a low-tempo R&B beat, offering several occasions of reverb to build upon the celestial imagery in this track. “supernatural“ in its simplest terminology, from Merriam-Webster means “of or relating to an order of existence beyond the visible observable universe” In relation to both the nature of the film this album is based on ’Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind’ as well as Ariana’s own personal affairs – this term directly correlates, in emotion, to how Ariana feels ‘inseperable’; feeling it take over her entire state of mind, and not minding at all. She constructs this sense through extended metaphors and semantics of togetherness, like when she states the situation is akin ‘like the moon needs the stars’ – the celestial nature suggested here may also be an allusion towards sexual intercourse, likening an orgasm to a supernatural experience. Ariana is also heavily superstitious, believing in the ‘supernatural’, therefore, it is fitting how Ariana suggests that it is some exterior power pulling them together, not fighting it as it’s part of the being's will. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

It was released on May 3, 2024 through Warner Records. “We made this whole record in a room in London in a studio in Kensal Rise. And that became my home for a year and a half and I have this big thing about studios because I love a place that has windows and light. A lot of studios don’t have that. That room has seen me through every season, has seen me through every emotion. Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: "Anything For Love" is the ninth track from Dua Lipa's third studio album, Radical Optimism. It was released on May 3, 2024 through Warner Records. “We made this whole record in a room in London in a studio in Kensal Rise. And that became my home for a year and a half and I have this big thing about studios because I love a place that has windows and light. A lot of studios don’t have that. That room has seen me through every season, has seen me through every emotion. I feel like my ideas can breathe in a room like that. And we were all together in the room, and engineer Jan, who’d been there for the whole year and a half with us helping us like set the mics up and do everything, he’s a super talented piano player. I asked him to play for us in that moment. I was like “Jan I think you should be a part of this track as well” and he came and played. It was just beautiful to have the energy of all the people who have played a little role in making this record with me. It was really just me on an SM7 kind of mic in the room making “Anything For Love”. “Anything For Love” I guess is this idea that we live in such a fast world where it feels like things are easy to dispose of. So people don’t really fight for things that they really care about or they’re very quick to let go of things that are meaningful. And in that sense that’s where I went in for “Anything For Love”. It’s like remember the time when people really fought for something or love really meant something, and it wasn’t just this throwaway thing? So that’s really where that song stemmed from.“ — via Zach Sang Show Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

The first verse pictures a young Kendrick deluded by money, whilst the second is the perspective of “Uncle Sam” – a personification of the U.S Government and White America – trying to charm him. In other words, Wesley's Theory illustrates how America (represented by Uncle Sam) Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: “Wesley’s Theory” establishes the album’s theme by describing how racist American institutions upheld by white supremacy exploit Black creators for profit. The first verse pictures a young Kendrick deluded by money, whilst the second is the perspective of “Uncle Sam” – a personification of the U.S Government and White America – trying to charm him. In other words, Wesley's Theory illustrates how America (represented by Uncle Sam) exploits financially illiterate rappers with newfound success (such as Kendrick after GKMC) by enticing them to purchase copious expensive items without realising they have to pay taxes for those items. First verse is Kendrick wanting to purchase items that are useless or causing further harm to his community (take a few M16s to the hood, pass em all out to the block)- literally misusing his influence. Second verse is Kendrick rapping as uncle Sam wanting to exploit Kendrick by enticing him to buy more and more expensive items until he has to pay taxes for all these items. The song’s title may be a nod to Wesley Snipes. The actor was embroiled in a tax fraud case throughout the 2000s and served a three-year jail sentence from 2010 to 2013. The U.S. Government stated Snipes was using “tax protester theory” in an attempt to get out of his charges. Lamar basically argues that what happened to Wesley snipes wasn’t just a mistake, but on purpose because the government encourages (black) people to spend beyond their means. Briefly, Kendrick brought his survival of Compton to the present to explain to everyone where he came from. He had to change or omit certain things to allow his listeners to feel such a state of euphoria. Something that at the time, Kendrick would not have felt. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "Free Woman" is an empowerment anthem encouraging women to take control of their lives and follow their dreams without the need to rely on a man. Gaga emphasizes the message of self-sufficiency, expressing her belief that women have the strength and confidence to blaze their own trails and make their own paths. The chorus follows the same message, emphasizing that being single is also something to be celebrated. The song encourages women to "be free" and not limit themselves just because they are not in a committed relationship. Read more on Last.fm.

lastfm_wiki_content: In the second single from her sophomore studio album, Silence Between Songs, Beer uses “Dangerous” to reflect back on her relationships, with both her partners and herself. The alluring track glides over simplistic piano chords as it builds up before majestical strings explode in the final chorus. During an Instagram Live on August 23, 2022, Beer added to the song and its meaning: I’m currently in my third long-term relationship and I’ve done a lot of self-reflection over the last two years – a whole lot of therapy, a whole lot of spiritual endeavors, and just learning about myself. Part of that, for me, has been to reflect. There have been times where I was like, “Is it me?” When you’re, like, the common denominator in something, am I the trauma? It’s one of those things where I had a moment of self-reflection. Being the dramatic Pisces I am, I definitely had times thinking, “Maybe I’m unlovable?” and I think we all go through phases of that. I’ve learned through therapy and a lot of love for myself, that I’m not, and I’m not too dangerous to love, but this song is about that feeling when you’re in that headspace. Read more on Last.fm. The lyrics convey the message that sometimes even the strongest person can break down, and they may want to hide their vulnerability from others. However, the woman in the song wants to be perceived as someone who will never give up, even though she may cry behind closed doors. The slow piano production used in the song creates a melancholic atmosphere that can tug at the heartstrings of the listeners Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: “Wonder Woman” describes a strong and resilient woman who has lived a thousand lives and experienced pain, but still remains strong. The lyrics convey the message that sometimes even the strongest person can break down, and they may want to hide their vulnerability from others. However, the woman in the song wants to be perceived as someone who will never give up, even though she may cry behind closed doors. The slow piano production used in the song creates a melancholic atmosphere that can tug at the heartstrings of the listeners, perfectly matching the introspective and sorrowful lyrics. Miley’s emotive vocals blend seamlessly with the gentle yet haunting notes of the piano, enhancing the somber ambiance of the track. The slow tempo of the song allows for a deep dive into the emotions of the lyrics, and Miley’s voice effectively conveys the pain and vulnerability, making the listeners feel connected to the persona’s experiences. “Wonder Woman” can be highly reminiscent of some of Miley’s notable tracks like, “Slide Away,” “The Climb,” “Wrecking Ball,” “Adore You,” and “Malibu,” which have a similar theme about perseverance and personal growth, which are also present in the song. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "Training Season" is a song by the English-Albanian singer Dua Lipa. It was released on 15 February 2024, as the second single from her third studio album, Radical Optimism. Lipa premiered the song at the 66th Annual Grammy Awards. Earlier in 2023, Dua Lipa announced her upcoming third studio album would be released sometime in 2024 with a new sound that sees her moving away from the disco sound of Future Nostalgia (2020), embracing more of 1970s-era psychedelia After having deleted all of her Instagram posts in October 2023 Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: "Training Season" is a song by the English-Albanian singer Dua Lipa. It was released on 15 February 2024, as the second single from her third studio album, Radical Optimism. Lipa premiered the song at the 66th Annual Grammy Awards. Earlier in 2023, Dua Lipa announced her upcoming third studio album would be released sometime in 2024 with a new sound that sees her moving away from the disco sound of Future Nostalgia (2020), embracing more of 1970s-era psychedelia After having deleted all of her Instagram posts in October 2023, Lipa posted a picture of herself with red hair captioned "miss me?". Following the single "Houdini" (2023), Lipa released "Training Season" as the second single from her upcoming album on 15 February 2024. The singer previously teased the song title through a picture she shared on Instagram, wearing a sweater with the caption "Training Season" during a rehearsal. On 24 January 2024 Lipa shared an instrumental snippet of the song through WhatsApp. She announced the single the following day through her social media. Written by Lipa, along with Caroline Ailin, Danny L Harle, Tobias Jesso Jr., and Kevin Parker, the song was produced by the latter and Harle. On 25 January, Lipa shared a clip of "Training Season" on TikTok. Its lyrics, which she conceived after going on mediocre dates, are about her denouncing unimpressive suitors. The clip featured Lipa singing lyrics over a pounding beat: "I need someone to hold me close, deeper than I've ever known/ Whose love feels like a rodeo, knows just how to take control." She elaborated on the dual meaning of its lyrics, stating that it is about both informing men that she will no longer be training them about how to treat her as well as the completion of her own personal growth. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "No Surprises" is a song by the British alternative rock band Radiohead. It was released as the third and final single from the group's 1997 album "OK Computer". Accompanied by a music video that featured a single shot of singer Thom Yorke's head in a plastic bubble that filled with water, the single peaked at number four in the United Kingdom. Radiohead wrote "No Surprises" while touring with the band R.E.M. in 1995. "No Surprises" was the first song Radiohead recorded on the first day of recording sessions for OK Computer. Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: "No Surprises" is a song by the British alternative rock band Radiohead. It was released as the third and final single from the group's 1997 album "OK Computer". Accompanied by a music video that featured a single shot of singer Thom Yorke's head in a plastic bubble that filled with water, the single peaked at number four in the United Kingdom. Radiohead wrote "No Surprises" while touring with the band R.E.M. in 1995. "No Surprises" was the first song Radiohead recorded on the first day of recording sessions for OK Computer. The version of the song on the album is the first take recorded. Singer Thom Yorke commented, "We did endless versions afterwards [...] and they were all just covers of the first version. So we gave up and went back to [the original]." The lyrics originally told the story of a man who has become fed up with the way things are working out for him and is having problems with his girlfriend. Two lines from this version are, "He was sick of her excuses / To not take off her dress when bleedin' in the bathroom." Preparing to record the song, Yorke altered the lyrics dramatically; instead of telling a love story about a man and his girlfriend, the song now appears to figuratively reference taking one's own life (as evidenced in lyrics such as "I'll take a quiet life/A handshake/Of carbon monoxide") to illustrate contempt for the complacency of British "normality". "No Surprises" was released as the third single from OK Computer on 12 January 1998. The single reached number four on the UK Singles Chart. The music video for "No Surprises" was directed by Grant Gee. The video consists solely of a single close-up shot of Thom Yorke's head inside a clear plastic bubble. The lyrics to the song scroll backwards on the bottom of the screen throughout the video. After the first verse, the plastic helmet begins to fill with water. Yorke continues singing as he attempts to lift his head above the rising water. Once the bubble completely fills, Yorke is motionless for over a minute, after which the water is released and he resumes singing. For Yorke's safety, the video was filmed at high-speed and played back in slow-motion. "No Surprises" was used in the opening episode of the 6th season of House, that shows Hugh Laurie's character suffering from pain due to Vicodin withdrawals. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "Crash My Party" is a song written by Rodney Clawson and Ashley Gorley and recorded by American country music artist Luke Bryan. It was released in April 2013 as the first single and title track from Bryan's fourth studio album of the same name. Bryan debuted the song at the Academy of Country Music awards in April 2013, which he hosted with Blake Shelton. "Crash My Party" debuted at #28 on the U.S. Billboard Country Airplay chart for the week of April 27, 2013. Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: "Crash My Party" is a song written by Rodney Clawson and Ashley Gorley and recorded by American country music artist Luke Bryan. It was released in April 2013 as the first single and title track from Bryan's fourth studio album of the same name. Bryan debuted the song at the Academy of Country Music awards in April 2013, which he hosted with Blake Shelton. "Crash My Party" debuted at #28 on the U.S. Billboard Country Airplay chart for the week of April 27, 2013. It also debuted at #35 on the U.S. Billboard Hot Country Songs chart for the week of April 20, 2013. It also debuted at #18 on the U.S. Billboard Hot 100 chart for the week of April 27, 2013. It also debuted at #18 on the Canadian Hot 100 chart for the week of April 27, 2013. As of January 2014, the song has sold 1,593,000 copies in the United States. Read more on Last.fm. lastfm_wiki_summary: "Idioteque" is the eighth track on Radiohead's album, Kid A. Driven by electronic beats, it was seen as a departure for the rock band, but remains a fan favourite, especially at live concerts. Singer Thom Yorke usually dances during the song, and the crowd joins in singing the second verse ("Ice age coming, ice age coming"). The song has been played at nearly every concert since 2001. The song features a prominent sample from "Track page: Mild und Leise" - an experimental computer piece from 1973 by electronic music pioneer Paul Lansky. Read more on Last.fm.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "Wildcard" seems to be about Miley's desire to be in a committed relationship, but at the same time acknowledging that she has a tendency to be unpredictable and possibly unreliable. She hints at this in the first verse where she asks if the listener wants to play house and she could be their wife, but at the same time notes that she is a "wildcard". The lyrics in the chorus emphasize her unpredictability and the fact that loving her may not be enough, and that forever may never come. Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: "Wildcard" seems to be about Miley's desire to be in a committed relationship, but at the same time acknowledging that she has a tendency to be unpredictable and possibly unreliable. She hints at this in the first verse where she asks if the listener wants to play house and she could be their wife, but at the same time notes that she is a "wildcard". The lyrics in the chorus emphasize her unpredictability and the fact that loving her may not be enough, and that forever may never come. In the second verse, she describes entering a room with her lips stained red and the flowers dead, indicating that she may have been out late or doing something that is not typical of a committed lover. However, in the bridge, she expresses her desire for a full commitment, but at a cost, and wants all or nothing. The repeated pre-chorus and chorus lyrics emphasize that she is a wildcard and that love alone may not be enough for her. Overall, the song seems to be a reflection of Cyrus' own personality and her desire for love but also her fear of commitment and her need for freedom. It is the tenth track from Miley Cyrus's æeighth studio album, Endless Summer Vacation. Read more on Last.fm. lastfm_wiki_content: “DAUGHTER” finds Beyoncé’s character struggling with violent thoughts in the face of infidelity, which cause her to recognize qualities of her father in her thinking. She more fully embodies the roles of protector assumed in previous tracks as she acts on threats against a woman who has eyes for her partner. Throughout, she warns that she is not harmless and can become like her father–she is his daughter, after all. The song features Beyoncé singing an Italian opera song called “Caro Mio Ben” –included because it narrates about the loneliness felt by the absence of his loved one, and the cruelty he inflicts on her. Band member Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: “Never Enough” is the 8th song on One Direction’s fifth studio album, Made in the A.M. This song was leaked twice, in the form of a hotel video in July 2015, and once again with the majority of the album during an early listening party in November 2015. With trumpets blaring and the band’s occasional grunting, this song is said to have a “jungle” vibe. This song is co-written by Niall Horan, Julian Bunetta, and John Ryan. Band member Niall cited this as his favorite song off the album stating it was “different from anything [they’ve] ever done” Musically uptempo, this song is clearly influenced by the contributions of Ladysmith Black Mambazo to Paul Simon’s Graceland. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "Shirt" is about the emotional struggle of being in a relationship where trust is difficult and worth is not always felt. The speaker is trying to navigate the power dynamics in the relationship and comes to the realization that they need more in order to stay in it. The bloodstain on the shirt could symbolize the pain and hurt from the relationship. The new bitch on their nerves could refer to their inner dissatisfaction or the idea of temptation to look elsewhere. Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: "Shirt" is about the emotional struggle of being in a relationship where trust is difficult and worth is not always felt. The speaker is trying to navigate the power dynamics in the relationship and comes to the realization that they need more in order to stay in it. The bloodstain on the shirt could symbolize the pain and hurt from the relationship. The new bitch on their nerves could refer to their inner dissatisfaction or the idea of temptation to look elsewhere. The old men being curved could refer to the difficulties of trusting someone and rebuilding a newfound connection or past hurt. The idea of being thirsty could refer to the need for attachment and validation of worth. The stress over perfection being discussed could be the speaker's own struggles with not being seen as worthy or the constant need to be "perfect" within the relationship. The final lines reflect thespeaker's realization that they are looking too desperate and may not be getting their worth in the relationship. Read more on Last.fm. lastfm_wiki_summary: "R.E.M." is the fourth track from Ariana Grande's fourth studio album, Sweetener (2018). The song is based on a Beyoncé demo titled "Wake Up", a leftover from her 2013 self-titled album, Beyoncé, which was also written and produced by Pharrell. The song never made it to the album and was scrapped. Four years later, Pharrell began working with Ariana Grande on her fourth album. He gave the song to her, which she rerecorded and titled "R.E.M." She says that "it's an entirely new song now." Read more on Last.fm.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "Lucky" is a song by the English rock band Radiohead, first released on The Help Album, a 1995 charity compilation organised by the charity War Child. "Lucky" was recorded in five hours with the producer Nigel Godrich. Radiohead included it on their third studio album, OK Computer, and released it as a single in France in December 1997. From Ed's sweet, tingling, opening riff, the rest of "Lucky" was generated. "I remember fiddling around in the sound check," he says. Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: "Lucky" is a song by the English rock band Radiohead, first released on The Help Album, a 1995 charity compilation organised by the charity War Child. "Lucky" was recorded in five hours with the producer Nigel Godrich. Radiohead included it on their third studio album, OK Computer, and released it as a single in France in December 1997. From Ed's sweet, tingling, opening riff, the rest of "Lucky" was generated. "I remember fiddling around in the sound check," he says. "[We] were in Japan- and putting together a different pedal order and actually hitting the strings above the nut on the headstock. The pedals that I did it with, and the delay that was going on. It was one of those moments -'Yeah, this is pretty cool'" From here, "Lucky" was made into what the band considers a "happy" song, or at least as happy a song as they are capable of creating. An identical version, which can be found on both the Help! compilation and the Help! EP, also appears on OK Computer. This wasn't the plan: the band did try to remix the track for the third album but found they couldn't improve on it. In 1995, Radiohead were on tour, promoting their second album, The Bends. During soundchecks for shows in Japan, guitarist Ed O'Brien produced a high-pitched sound by strumming above the guitar nut. The band developed the sound into a song, "Lucky", which became part of the set list. Around this time, the producer Brian Eno asked Radiohead to contribute a song to The Help Album, a charity compilation organised by the charity War Child. The album was to be recorded in a single day, 4 September 1995, and rush-released that week. Radiohead recorded "Lucky" in five hours with engineer Nigel Godrich, who had assisted producer John Leckie with The Bends and produced several Radiohead B-sides Godrich went on to produce their third album, OK Computer. He said of the Help Album session: "Those things are the most inspiring, when you do stuff really fast and there's nothing to lose. We left feeling fairly euphoric." Yorke later said "Lucky" shaped the nascent sound and mood of OK Computer. He said: "'Lucky' was indicative of what we wanted to do. It was like the first mark on the wall." Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "Love Me Do" is The Beatles' first single, backed by "P.S. I Love You" and released on 5 October 1962. When the single was originally released in the United Kingdom, it peaked at number seventeen; in 1982 it was re-issued and reached number four. In the United States the single was a number one hit in 1964. In January 2013, the Beatles' recording of "Love Me Do" entered the public domain in Europe/Canada, as sound recordings were copyright-protected for 50 years. The copyright term was later extended to 70 years, which was not retroactive. Read more on Last.fm.

lastfm_wiki_summary: “Happiness Is a Butterfly" (stylized in sentence case) appears to be about the fleeting nature of happiness and the desire to chase it. The song conveys a sense of confusion and uncertainty in relationships, as the singer questions whether the person she is with truly wants to be with her. The metaphor of a butterfly for happiness suggests that it is elusive and difficult to catch, particularly at night when it disappears into the moonlight. The pre-chorus contemplates the potential risks and consequences of pursuing a relationship Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: “Happiness Is a Butterfly" (stylized in sentence case) appears to be about the fleeting nature of happiness and the desire to chase it. The song conveys a sense of confusion and uncertainty in relationships, as the singer questions whether the person she is with truly wants to be with her. The metaphor of a butterfly for happiness suggests that it is elusive and difficult to catch, particularly at night when it disappears into the moonlight. The pre-chorus contemplates the potential risks and consequences of pursuing a relationship, even with someone who may have a dark past. The chorus repeats the desire for connection and intimacy, with the verses describing the search for happiness in a night out in Los Angeles. The post-chorus emphasizes the singer's longing for a simple connection through dance, which seems to be the closest she can get to capturing the butterfly of happiness. The song appears to be a reflection of the challenges of finding meaningful connections in a confusing world and the struggle to maintain happiness in the face of uncertainty and disappointment. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

Travis Scott confirmed the song’s release for UTOPIA on July 22, 2023 at his Rolling Loud set where it was displayed along with 4 other titles in the fictional Utopian language from Thomas More’s 1516 book Utopia. The track was additionally released as a single right when UTOPIA had dropped. Read more on Last.fm.

lastfm_wiki_summary: “NO BYSTANDERS” sees Travis Scott collaborating with Juice WRLD and Sheck Wes, who was signed to Travis' label, Cactus Jack three days after the track. This song is featured on Travis' long-awaited third studio album, ASTROWORLD. Juice claimed he really wanted to collaborate with Travis and that he was still stuck listening to Travis' debut studio album, Rodeo. However, Sheck handles the chorus of the track. The chorus was the most controversial part of the song because it interpolates the chorus of Three 6 Mafia’s 1995 track Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: “NO BYSTANDERS” sees Travis Scott collaborating with Juice WRLD and Sheck Wes, who was signed to Travis' label, Cactus Jack three days after the track. This song is featured on Travis' long-awaited third studio album, ASTROWORLD. Juice claimed he really wanted to collaborate with Travis and that he was still stuck listening to Travis' debut studio album, Rodeo. However, Sheck handles the chorus of the track. The chorus was the most controversial part of the song because it interpolates the chorus of Three 6 Mafia’s 1995 track, “Tear da Club Up ‘97, where the group raps: "Tear da club up, nigga, tear da club up" "Tear da club up, nigga, tear da club up" Travis was eventually legally sued by DJ Paul from Three 6 Mafia for copyright. In September 2019, word spread that the lawsuit was settled by Travis paying the requested $20 million. Hours before the album’s release, Travis used this song title along with other ASTROWORLD tracks, consisting of “NC-17,” “STARGAZING,” and “STOP TRYING TO BE GOD” to promote the album on his now-expired Instagram story. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "Pray You Catch Me" is the opening track from Beyoncé's sixth studio album, Lemonade. She introduces the suspicion, pain and emotional intimacy that will drive the whole album. NME's Larry Bartleet described the song as a "piano and strings-backed ballad. Everest True from The Independent described it as a "stately, intense and secret – there is just the occasional throb of bass and softened beat to accentuate her message. With other lyrics, this could be a love song". Read more on Last.fm.

lastfm_wiki_summary: The ambiguous, six minute long “She” can be interpreted in an array of meanings. While the song appears to touch on the protagonist spending his days picturing himself with someone other than who he’s with, the song can also take an introspective approach towards the examination of the protagonist’s gender identity. Styles has never confirmed what exactly the song is about, which has allowed for multiple interpretations of its meaning. Harry Styles channels a character who is fantasizing about his ideal girl. Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: The ambiguous, six minute long “She” can be interpreted in an array of meanings. While the song appears to touch on the protagonist spending his days picturing himself with someone other than who he’s with, the song can also take an introspective approach towards the examination of the protagonist’s gender identity. Styles has never confirmed what exactly the song is about, which has allowed for multiple interpretations of its meaning. Harry Styles channels a character who is fantasizing about his ideal girl. A married office worker, his daydreams liven up his humdrum existence. Harry experimented with magic mushrooms during the recording of "Fine Line". The former One Direction star admitted to Rolling Stone that he took the hallucinogenic drug at a LA recording studio and bit the end of his tongue off while under the influence. "She," which he wrote with his guitar sidekick Mitch Rowland, was penned while they were taking them. "We had no idea what we were doing," he recalled. "We forgot all about that track, then went back later and loved it. But Mitch had no idea what he did on guitar that night, so he had to learn it all over from the track." Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

lastfm_wiki_summary: “ASTROTHUNDER” features production from frequent collaborator Frank Dukes and Frank Ocean affiliate Vegyn, whilst also providing Travis' first collaboration with John Mayer and Thundercat. In 2014, producer Vinylz uploaded a since deleted Instagram/Twitter post detailing a potential collaboration between Travis and John Mayer. The song’s title seemingly references Thundercat, owing to his distinctive basslines and also adding to his long list of high profile collaborations. Read more on Last.fm.

lastfm_wiki_content: The song is about a star who had it all- and who was also exposed to all, the tabloids, lights, and cameras. After her secrets were being leaked all over the world she was done, she moved away to a life of solitude and nobody knew where she had gone. Swift reportedly wrote this song in Australia, and although she doesn’t say who the song is about (she set a rule against this herself), the song is rumored to be about Joni Mitchell and Kim Wilde, the lyrics: “They say you bought a bunch of land somewhere, chose the rose garden over Madison Square.” could possibly be referencing how Wilde left her career to become a landscape gardener. The main melody is also sampled from Wilde’s “Four Letter Word” The song ends with Taylor understanding why the star chose that path, and how Taylor feels that she’s becoming the “The Lucky One”. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.

lastfm_wiki_summary: "Zanzibar" is a song written by Billy Joel that first appeared on his 1978 album 52nd Street. It has also appeared on several live albums. It is particularly notable for the jazz trumpet breaks played by Freddie Hubbard. The themes of "Zanzibar" include love of sports, love of alcohol and the singer's attempt to pick up a waitress. According to producer Phil Ramone, Joel had written the music and had decided he liked the title "Zanzibar" for the piece, but had not figured out what to say about Zanzibar. Read more on Last.fm.
lastfm_wiki_content: "Zanzibar" is a song written by Billy Joel that first appeared on his 1978 album 52nd Street. It has also appeared on several live albums. It is particularly notable for the jazz trumpet breaks played by Freddie Hubbard. The themes of "Zanzibar" include love of sports, love of alcohol and the singer's attempt to pick up a waitress. According to producer Phil Ramone, Joel had written the music and had decided he liked the title "Zanzibar" for the piece, but had not figured out what to say about Zanzibar. Hearing the music conjured up for Ramone images of people watching television in a bar, and as a result Joel decided to make the song about activity in a sports bar named Zanzibar rather than about the country Zanzibar. The lyrics include a number of contemporary sports references, including to heavyweight champion boxer Muhammad Ali, baseball player Pete Rose, and the baseball team the New York Yankees, who were the World Champions at the time. The lyrics also use a baseball expression as a sexual metaphor when the singer wants to steal second base with a waitress in the bar if the waitress will allow it. Joel biographer Hank Bordowitz considers the waitress to be a metaphor for Joel's first wife Elizabeth, similar to how he considers the waitress "practicing politics" in Joel's earlier song "Piano Man" to be a metaphor for Elizabeth. The song begins with a short slow section, but then moves to a shuffle rhythm. It contains two jazz trumpet solos played by the legendary jazz trumpeter Freddie Hubbard. The song's bridge begins with a "dreamy" keyboard section, which leads into the first trumpet solo. According to Ramone, the urgency and sexiness of the trumpet part is enhanced by the ascending and descending line played on bass guitar beneath the solo. The second solo comes at the end of the song and goes into the fades out. Of playing with Hubbard, Joel stated that it "was a special treat for me, because I've always admired and respected jazz players." Joel also recalled that after playing with Hubbard on the song, drummer Liberty DeVitto claimed that "Now I feel like a grown up." Allmusic critic Stephen Thomas Erlewine considers the melody of "Zanzibar" to be homage to Steely Dan's Donald Fagen. Ramone claims that he convinced Joel to experiment with creating a jazz mood on the 52nd Street album based on the fact that Joel had written some jazz riffs into the end of "Zanzibar." Billy Joel biographer Mark Bego claims that "If 52nd Street is Billy's tribute to jazz, then 'Zanzibar' is its centerpiece." "Zanzibar" was the third most played album cut from "52nd Street" on U.S. album-oriented rock radio during 1979 according to the year-end R&R Top 79 Albums of 1979 chart. "Zanzibar" has often featured in Joel's live concerts. Since 2005 the trumpet solos have been performed by Carl Fischer. Live performances have been included on the 2006 album 12 Gardens Live and the 2008 album Live at Shea Stadium: The Concert. A live performance also appears in the video The Last Play at Shea. In later performances, Joel alters the lyrics about Pete Rose, reflecting his ban from baseball resulting from gambling allegations. Instead of singing of Rose being "a credit to the game," Joel jokes that he will "never make the Hall of Fame." "Zanzibar" was also included on the compilation album My Lives. The version on My Lives contains different trumpet solos performed by Hubbard. In addition, this version does not fade out the second trumpet solo that ends the song, providing an extra minute and a half of Hubbard's playing. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.
